lines.text: [Wild Bill and Calamity Jane are interrupted by Jack McCall during a romantic moment]
You inconsiderate bastard.
[Will Plummer sends in a woman to challenge Wild Bill to a gunfight]
What did he say?
He said that you were a horse molester.
He say what horse?
[Jane surprises Bill by giving him a wet sloppy kiss]
Just for old times' sake.
[Bill wipes off his mouth]
You wipin' it off?
No. I'm rubbin' it in.
This town... I really think it's like something out of the Bible.
What part of the Bible?
The part right before God gets angry.
What kind of whiskey do you favor?
Carl, I prefer it in a glass. Other than that, it's all good.

[to Bill]
Bad luck to kill an Indian in a religious frame of mind.
You ought to know better than to touch another man's hat.

[to McCall]
I'll buy you one. Whiskey's good for a man... helps him put things in perspective.
A man that cgeats at cards ain't got no religion.

He had found the band of jackals he needed. But as Jack McCall rode through the center of town, he experienced the terrifying certainty that a man faces when he's about to make his own name famous. He lacked both a hero's calm and a coward's resolve to survive at any price.

[Voiceover about Hickock]
He fashioned himself as just an ordinary man in no way special. That was adeception. By luck or design it had fallen to him to play the hero's part, and to the end he embraced his fate.
[last lines]

Jack McCall was hanged March 1, 1877, for the murder of James Butler Hickory, known as Wild Bill. Like a city in the Old Testament, Deadwood had become a place of prophesy and visions. Bill was 39 years old when he died. I'm proud to say I was his friend.
